course.title: Orientation to Textiles, Merchandising and Fashion Design

description.div:
Introduction to Textiles, Merchandising and Fashion Design programs, activities, resources, and careers.
NOTE: Required of all freshmen and transfer students in the Department of Textiles, Merchandising and Fashion Design programs.
Technical experience in stitch applications, garment construction and finishes and fundamental fit.

An introduction to design fundamentals and their application in visual communications. Design problems and solutions will be explored and considered relative to the needs of various professions that use images to convey information.
Analysis of social, cultural, aesthetic, and economic influences on clothing and human behavior.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

description.div: Analysis of social, cultural, aesthetic, and economic influences on clothing and human behavior.

course.title: Visual Literacy Lab: Analysis and/or Composition

prerequisite.div: ARTP: Art major or candidate for teaching endorsement in art. ARCH: Admission to the College of Architecture. IDES: Admission to the College of Architecture. JGEN: College of Journalism and Mass Communications major and 2.75 GPA. LARC: Admission to the College of Architecture. TMFD: Textiles, Merchandising and Design major or minor.

description.div: Development of creative and perceptual analytic skills through problem solving in design. Composition and analysis.

prerequisite.div: ARTP: Art major or candidate for teaching endorsement in art. ARCH: Admission to the College of Architecture. IDES: Admission to the College of Architecture. JGEN: College of Journalism and Mass Communications major and 2.75 GPA. LARC: Admission to the College of Architecture. TMFD: Textiles, Merchandising and Design major or minor.

description.div: Development of creative and perceptual analytic skills through problem solving in drawing and design. Composition and perceptual drawing.

prerequisite.div: ARTP: Art major or candidate for teaching endorsement in art. ARCH: Admission to the College of Architecture. IDES: Admission to the College of Architecture. JGEN: College of Journalism and Mass Communications major and 2.75 GPA. LARC: Admission to the College of Architecture. TMFD: Textiles, Merchandising and Design major or minor.

description.div: Development of creative and perceptual analytic skills through problem solving in drawing and design. Composition and color theory application.

prerequisite.div: ARTP: Art major or candidate for teaching endorsement in art. ARCH: Admission to the College of Architecture. IDES: Admission to the College of Architecture. JGEN: College of Journalism and Mass Communications major and 2.75 GPA. LARC: Admission to the College of Architecture. TMFD: Textiles, Merchandising and Design major or minor.

description.div: Development of creative and perceptual analytic skills through problem solving in drawing and design. Composition and perceptual drawing.

prerequisite.div: ARTP: Art major or candidate for teaching endorsement in art. ARCH: Admission to the College of Architecture. IDES: Admission to the College of Architecture. JGEN: College of Journalism and Mass Communications major and 2.75 GPA. LARC: Admission to the College of Architecture. TMFD: Textiles, Clothing and Design major or minor.

description.div: Introduction to issues in Visual Literacy as they relate to art and design. Formal and critical analysis.

prerequisite.div: Sophomore standing.

description.div: Fibers, yarns, fabric construction, and finishes as they affect use and care.

course.title: Product Development I: Apparel Analysis and Development

description.div: Analysis and evaluation of apparel structure. Design, style, and construction variations as related to quality, price, and performance.

course.title: Merchandising I: Textile and Apparel Industry

description.div: Textile and apparel industry processes. Social, cultural, and economic influences on the industry including entrepreneurship.

prerequisite.div: TMFD 103 and 212.

description.div: Creative experience in apparel design through the use of flat pattern methods.

prerequisite.div: For Merchandising or Textile Science option: ARTP/ARCH/IDES/JGEN/LARC/TMFD 141A and 141B. For Textile, Merchandising and Fashion Design Communications option: ARTP/ARCH/IDES/JGEN/LARC/TMFD 140A and 140B. For Textiles and Apparel Design option: ARPT/ARCH/IDES/JGEN/LARC/TMFD 140A, 140B, 141A, 141B, and 143.

description.div: Introduction to surface design with creative applications of printing and dyeing techniques on fabric.

course.title: Product Development II: Fashion Analysis and Presentation

prerequisite.div: TMFD major. For Merchandising or Textile Science option: ARTP/ARCH/IDES/JGEN/LARC/TMFD 141A and 141B. For Textiles, Merchandising and Fashion Design Communications option: ARTP/ARCH/IDES/JGEN/LARC/TMFD 140A and 140B. For Textiles and Apparel Design option: ARTP/ARCH/IDES/JGEN/LARC/TMFD 140A, 140B, 141A, 141B, and 143; TMFD 212.

description.div: Drawing garments and the fashion figure. Aesthetic styling and presentation, refining product specifications, and interpretations of current trends. Intermediate application of computer-aided design in flat drawings and visual presentations.

course.title: Merchandising II: Merchandise Buying and Control

prerequisite.div: ACCT 200 and 3 hrs MATH.

description.div: Role and responsibilities of apparel and/or home furnishings merchandisers in a retail operation. Fundamentals of merchandise mathematics and its application to computer technology.

course.title: Textiles and Apparel Merchandising and Promotion

prerequisite.div: For Merchandising or Textile Science option: ARTP/ARCH/IDES/JGEN/LARC/TMFD: 141A and 141B. For Textiles, Merchandising and Fashion Design Communications option: ARTP/ARCH/IDES/JGEN/LARC/TMFD: 140A and 140B. For Textiles and Apparel Design option: ARTP/ARCH/IDES/JGEN/LARC/TMFD 140A, 140B, 141A, 141B, 143; or ARCH 210.

description.div: Store and non-store visual merchandising and promotion for textiles and apparel. Includes strategies for branding and target market in both real and virtual platforms.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; TMFD 206.

description.div: Creative application of woven and non-loom textile construction techniques.
Readings in current literature and individual problems.

prerequisite.div: TMFD 212 and 216.

description.div: Creative experience in designing apparel through the use of draping techniques.

prerequisite.div: TMFD 206; CHEM 105 or 109 or 113.

description.div: Recent advances in the production and performance of fibers, yarns, finishes and dyes for textile products. Lab experiences designed to familiarize the students with standards, methods and equipment for evaluating textile product performance.

prerequisite.div: TMFD 206.

description.div: Physical and chemical analysis of textiles using standard testing procedures. The calculation, interpretation, and evaluation of test results.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing, AHIS 101 or 102 or 3 hrs HIST 100 or 101.

description.div: Theoretical approach to the history of dress from ancient times through the twentieth century; examining dress in the context of social, economic, and artistic development of Western culture.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing, TMFD 206, AHIS 101 or 102 or 3 hrs HIST 100 or 101.

description.div: Textiles in the context of artistic, social, political, and economic developments in the cultures of Europe, Asia, Africa and the Americas. Emphasis on evolution of textile design and stylistic differences between cultures.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing; 3 hrs PSYC or SOCI; TMFD 123.

description.div: Theories and research findings about the social and psychological aspects of clothing and appearance in relation to the self and others.

course.title: Product Development III: Trend Analysis and Product Conceptualization

prerequisite.div: Senior Standing; For Merchandising option and for the Textile and Apparel Design option: TMFD 312, MRKT 300 and 6 hrs from any of the the following: ACCT 200, ECON 200, BLAW 300, FINA 300, MNGT 300. For Textile Science option and for the Textile, Merchandising and Fashion Design Communications option: TMFD 312 and ECON 200.

description.div: Synthesis of process involved in product development from product initiation to the development of market strategies. Career and portfolio development.

course.title: Merchandising III: Textiles and Apparel Merchandise Development and Retail Strategies

prerequisite.div: ACCT 200; MRKT 300 and 3 hrs from any of the following: ECON 200, BLAW 300, FINA 300, MNGT 300; TMFD 313 and 314.

description.div: Problems involved in consumer decision making, merchandise development and planning, retail strategies, and marketing practices specific to the textile and apparel industry.
Designing apparel, computer-aided design, pattern making, and line development for specific markets.

prerequisite.div: Senior Standing and TMFD 313

description.div: Comprehensive study of issues involved in global sourcing, including the scope, trends, and sustainability of current practices. An analysis of cultural, political, ethical, and economic perspectives related to global sourcing, production, trade and distribution of textiles and apparel products.

prerequisite.div: TMFD 123 and 225.

description.div: Digital and other media for printed textiles. Design development, professional practices, and expressive and communicative concepts.

prerequisite.div: 4 hrs CHEM and TMFD 206.

notes.div: This course is taught every other year. Check with adviser and/or department when planning course work.

description.div: Application classes of dyes. Physical and chemical properties of dyes within each class, methods of dye-fiber association, fastness properties of dyes, and recommended application procedures.

prerequisite.div: TMFD 216; TMFD 225 or 325; TMFD 403 or 416; parallel TMFD 472.

description.div: Advanced work in the creation of apparel as visual communication. Design conceptualization with experimentation in media, structure, technique, and presentation.

prerequisite.div: TMFD 216 and 225; parallel TMFD 471. TMFD 325 and 403 recommended.

notes.div: TMFD 472 requires a public presentation of work.

description.div: Advanced work in creation of textiles. Design conceptualization, development and experimentation in media, structure, application, and product development.

prerequisite.div: Permission.

notes.div: Presented by department faculty and visiting artists, scholars and scientists.

description.div: Opportunity to analyze and evaluate techniques, develop skills, or study topics of special interest. A. Textiles (1-3 cr) B. Fashion (1-3 cr) D. Design (1-3 cr)

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs textiles, merchandising and fashion design or permission.

description.div: The textile and apparel industry. Visits to museums, showrooms, manufacturers, retail establishments in major domestic and/or foreign markets such as: New York City, Paris, London, Milan, Prague, Shanghai, Seoul.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in textiles, merchandising and fashion design and permission.

description.div: Individual projects in research, literature review, or creative production. A. Textiles (1-5 cr) B. Fashion (1-5 cr) D. Design (1-5 cr)

prerequisite.div: For all options: 2.5 GPA, 79 hrs completed toward the degree; 3.0 GPA in TMFD courses; plus any additional prerequisites that are required for the specific option as follows. For Merchandising option: TMFD 313 and 314. For Textiles Science option: TMFD 405/805 or 406/806. For Textiles, Merchandising and Fashion Design Communications option: TMFD 314 and 407/807 or 408/808 or 410/810. For Textile and Apparel Design option: TMFD 403/803 or 416/816 or 425.

notes.div: TMFD 498 requires an application for the internship with the TMFD department and with the employer. TMFD 498 is 'Letter Grade only'.

description.div: Supervised individual professional experience with a qualified cooperative practicing professional.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing.

course.title: Care and Conservation of Textile Collections

prerequisite.div: TMFD 206 or permission

description.div: Recommended practices for accessioning, handling, storage, exhibition, and preventative conservation of textiles and dress in museum collections. Philosophical and ethical issues confronting curators and collection managers.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs textiles, merchandising, and fashion design and permission

description.div:
Selected problems related to textiles, fashion, and design.
A. Textiles
B. Fashion
D. Design

course.title: Textiles and Dress: A Cultural Perspective

prerequisite.div: 6 hours of history or art history; TMFD 206

description.div: TMFD 807, 808, and ANTH 100 recommended. Textiles and dress as an expression of the life, arts and material culture of Europe, Asia, the Middle East, Africa and the Americas. Literature and theoretical approaches.

course.title: History of Quilts in the Western World

prerequisite.div: Permission

description.div: Influence of social, political, artistic and technological developments on quiltmaking traditions.

prerequisite.div: TMFD 212, 216, 312, and 803 or 816; or permission of instructor

description.div: Creative experience in designing textiles and apparel as three-dimensional art forms with emphasis on conceptualization, expression, media, techniques, lighting, space, and movement as influential factors combined with exhibition experience. Topics vary.

course.title: Rendering and Production of Textiles and/or Apparel

prerequisite.div: Permission of instructor

description.div: Studio experience in working with a variety of media, including digital, to render and produce textiles and/or apparel; and Portfolio development.

course.title: Advanced Work in Digital and Other Media for Textile Design

prerequisite.div: TMFD 225 and 325

description.div: Digital and other media for textiles. Design development, professional practice, and expressive communicative concepts.

course.title: Current Issues in Textiles, Fashion and Design

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs textiles, merchandising and fashion design and permission

description.div:
Significant issues in textiles, clothing, and fashion design.
A. Textiles
B. Fashion
D. Design
Lec 2, stu 2. TMFD 873 culminates in an exhibition in the Robert Hillestad Textiles Gallery. Contemporary issues in design with creative and/or curatorial work.
Emergence and synthesis of theory, current theoretical development, conceptual structures, theory construction as a framework for research and evaluation of scholarly publications.
Research methods that addresses practical and theoretical issues involved in designing, conducting, and evaluating research.

prerequisite.div: TMFD 206; TMFD 807 or 808

description.div: Research methods for material culture study applied to textiles and dress. Methodologies for artifact study and skills. Fiber microscopy as a tool for artifact analysis. Conceptual development, application and evaluation of a model for artifact study.

Workshops on a variety of topics by department faculty and visiting artists, scholars and scientists. Opportunity to analyze and evaluate techniques, develop skills, or study topics of special interest.
A. Textiles
B. Fashion
D. Design
Aspects of human sciences not covered elsewhere in the curriculum.

prerequisite.div: Admission to masters degree program and permission of major adviser
Permission of chair

description.div:
Reading, discussions, and reports dealing with the economic, sociological, historical, technical, and aesthetic phases of textiles and clothing.
A. Textiles
B. Clothing
D. Design

prerequisite.div: TMFD 813 plus 9 hrs textiles, merchandising and fashion design, 6 hrs economics (undergraduate hrs) or permission

description.div: Current status of the domestic textile and apparel complex; current theories of textile consumption and demand within the international market; factors influencing textile and apparel production, distribution, and expenditures; the role of international trade and its influence on the domestic textile and apparel industry and foreign policy.

course.title: Appearance and Space as Nonverbal Communication

prerequisite.div: TMFD 810, or permission

description.div: Appearance and space as systems of nonverbal communication with emphasis on their relationship to the development of the self and the micro and macro processes of life.

prerequisite.div: TMFD 813 or permission

description.div: Common theoretical frameworks found in the textile/apparel/interior merchandising and marketing literature, plus issues which impact the textiles and apparel industry.

prerequisite.div: CYAF 918 or permission of department chair

description.div: Supervised classroom experiences designed to develop competencies in teaching at the college level.
(1-3 cr per sem, max 9

course.title: Seminar in Textiles, Clothing, and Design

prerequisite.div: Permission
Permission

description.div: Intended primarily for doctoral students, although non-doctoral graduate students may be admitted with permission. Immersion in outcome-based scholarly activities with a faculty mentor. Develop, execute and report on one or more projects addressing the interaction between research and practice, individually or in small groups.

prerequisite.div: Permission
9 hrs textiles, clothing and design graduate credit

description.div: Supervised independent professional experience under direction of a practicing professional within the textile and apparel industry, government agencies, museums and/or businesses.

prerequisite.div: Permission
Admission to doctoral degree program and permission of supervisory committee chair
